newsitem.title: CANADA: Noranda blames poor metals prices for Q3.
newsitem.headline: Noranda blames poor metals prices for Q3.

text.p: Natural resources giant Noranda Inc reported lower third quarter earnings on Tuesday, blaming the downfall on lower metals volumes and lower prices for metals and newsprint.
Third quarter profits clocked in at C$51 million or C$0.20 per share, down from C$128 million or C$0.55 a share for the third quarter of 1995.
The decrease stems from lower copper, aluminum, nickel and newsprint prices as well as decreased volume from the mining and metals operations, the company said in a statement.
Higher gas, oil and lumber prices help offset the decline.

Noranda said the profits included one-time gains of C$22 million from Noranda's stake in Falconbridge Ltd less the costs associated with this summer's merger between Hemlo and Battle Mountain Gold Co.
Noranda owns 28 percent of Battle Mountain Gold.
Noranda's mining and metals group earned C$22 million in the third quarter compared to C$99 million last year.
Lower volumes from the company's Brunswick aluminum operation and from Falconbridge's base metals mine at Kidd Creek in Northern Ontario contributed to lower earnings, Noranda said.
"Looking toward 1997 we are optimistic that commodity prices, particularly some of the metals, will improve," chairman David Kerr said in a statement.
"We have several projects in hand designed to increase profitability."
